quote: We never cared what we did, as long    as it annoyed the grown-ups...       ... All inner deflector shield sub-   systems are showing equal intensity.
Power balance levels are reading    normal...       ... I was a champion window breaker.     On a dark night with a few rocks, I    was deadly.
Uh... which "you" are you talking    about?
We're being hailed by an incoming    freighter.
Open a channel.  On screen.
Welcome to DS Nine; I'm Major Kira    Nerys.
This is the Kobheerian freighter Rak-   Miunis, requesting permission to    dock.
Docking Port Six is clear for    approach.
Thank you.  We have a passenger on    board requiring medical assistance.
Can you tell us what's wrong with    your passenger?
He says it's a condition called Kalla-   Nohra.  It's apparently chronic, but    he doesn't have his medication.
Beam him directly to our Infirmary..    we'll have our doctor standing by.
Thank you, Commander.  Rak-Miunis    out.
Dax to Infirmary.
This is Bashir; go ahead.
A Kobheerian transport's about to    beam a patient to you.  He's suffering    from something called Kalla-Nohra.
I'm not aware of it... I'll check    the computer.
Commander, I'd like to go down to    the Infirmary and meet that patient.
Of course... Why?

The only cases of Kalla-Nohra I know    of were the result of a mining    accident at a Bajoran forced labor    camp I helped liberate.  The survivors    of Gallitep have always been a symbol    to us of strength and courage.
By all means, Major, take as long as    you want.
Ah, Major.  I'll be right with you.
Kira to Odo... I'm in the Infirmary.     I need security here on the double.
What's the matter, Major.
Your patient is a criminal.
Good afternoon.
I assume this is the problem?
Lock him up.
This is outrageous!  On what charge!
Will someone tell me what's going    on?  This man needs medical care!
Then give it to him.
In his cell.
But I haven't done anything!
Then why did you run?
I was trying to get away from this    Bajoran fanatic.  Look at the hate    in her eyes.  She'd like to kill me.
Oh?  And why would that be?
It's obvious.  I'm a Cardassian.
This one's not just any Cardassian.     He's a war criminal.
Marritza.  Aamin Marritza.
You're saying Marritza's on the    Bajoran's list of Cardassians wanted    for war crimes?
He's not on any list I've seen,    Commander; and I've got them all.
I don't care if he's listed or not...
Now hold it, Major.  Marritza's    traveling on a Federation ship.  He    comes here for a medical emergency,    and we throw him into a security    cell.  I, for one, hope he's listed.
Commander, I know what I've done    isn't exactly policy.  It may not    even be legal.  But it's right.
Okay, Major; what do we charge him    with?
I'm charging him with having    contracted Kalla-Nohra.
Do you want to explain that to me?
The only way he could have contracted    that condition was to have served at    the Gallitep labor camp at the time    of the mining accident.
And that makes him a war criminal.     Just being there?

Commander, if you had been there    twelve years ago when we liberated    the camp... If you had seen the things    I saw... All those Bajoran bodies...    starved, brutalized.  D'you know    what Cardassian policy was?  I don't    mean just the murder.  Murder was    only the end of the fun for them.     First came the humiliation... the    rape of mothers in front of their    children... Husbands beaten till their    wives couldn't recognize them... Old    people buried alive because they    couldn't work anymore...
I think I'll have a talk with our    guest.
I'll come with you.
No, Major.  It'd be better if I spoke    to him alone.
How do you feel?
Better, thank you.
I'm Benjamin Sisko; I'm in charge of    this station.
Ah; finally.  The Federation to the    rescue.  You are going to let me out    of here...
I hope so.  Tell me.  How did you    contract Kalla-Nohra syndrome?
I don't have Kalla-Nohra.  I have    Pottrik Syndrome.
The freighter captain told us it was    Kalla-Nohra.
Ah.  The two conditions are very    similar; same medication, as a matter    of fact.
Then you didn't serve at the Gallitep    labor camp?
Labor camp.  I've never even been to    Bajor.  I served as a military file    clerk.
I now reside on Kora Two, where I    boarded the freighter which,    unfortunately for me, came here.     Now, Commander, if you have no further    questions, I'd like to be on my way.
Am I still drunk, or am I in jail    with a Cardassian?       Odo!  You're not keeping me in here    with...       ... one of those!  Odo!
I put myself in your hands, Commander.
Let me get this straight.  You're    saying that Marritza does have Kalla-   Norha?
There's no doubt about it.  He has    all the symptoms.  And when I ran a    lower pulmonary bio-probe, it read    positive.
And you're sure he doesn't have    Pottrik Syndrome.
Absolutely.  If he had Pottrik's,    the bio-probe would've been negative.
Then he was at the Gallitep labor    camp.
Definitely.  I've cross-checked all    Bajoran and Federation medical    records, and there's simply no other    way he could've gotten that condition.
Kira to Sisko.
Yes, Major.
Commander, there's an incoming    transmission for you from Bajor.     It's the Minister of State.
Thank you.       If you'll excuse me, Doctor.
Minister Kaval.  Good day, Sir.
And to you, Commander.  I trust you're    in good health; things are going    well on the station... ?
Quite well, thank you.
That's wonderful.  I'm told you've    performed a special service for Bajor    today.  Congratulations to you.
I don't quite follow.
We are holding a Cardassian...    temporarily.
By "temporarily," you mean until    you're satisfied that a verified    identification has been made.
Minister, I'm not sure we have the    grounds to hold him that long.
I fully understand your concerns,    Commander, but...       ... since our Major Kira's accepted    responsibility in this matter, the    burden is off your shoulders.
I don't agree.
Commander, if this Marritza was at    Gallitep, we want him, and we will    have him.  Is that clear?
It is.
Good.       We'll chat again soon.  Good day,    Commander.
May I join you?
Actually, I was just about to pay a    visit to our friend Marritza.
That's what I wanted to talk to you    about, Major.       I'd like Odo to handle this    investigation.
Why?
He's our Chief of Security.
Minister Kaval put me in charge.
Minister Kaval doesn't run this    station.
And the Federation's got no right    telling us how to deal with our    criminals.
If it turns out he is a criminal,    he'll be yours and you're welcome to    him.  Until then, he's just a traveler    under suspicion.
You think this is all some personal    vendetta on my part, don't you?
I think you're too close to be    objective, yes.
You're right; I'm not objective.     But I'm your first officer, and I    give you my word that I'll conduct    myself accordingly.
You once said we were friends.  I'm    asking you now as a friend.  Please    let me conduct this investigation.     I owe it to them.
You mean the victims.
That's right; the ones who moved too    slowly and never moved again... I'm    asking for all the Bajorans who can't    ask... Let a Bajoran do this.
Sisko to Odo.
Go ahead.
Constable; Major Kira will be in    charge of the Marritza investigation.
I understand.
Sisko out.
Thank you.
Constable...
It's about time you let me out.
Try to stay out of trouble for a day    or two, will you?
I'll do my best.       Oh, and Odo... let me know when you    hang the Cardassian.

I've begun a background check on    Marritza.  So far he is what he says    he is.  He boarded that Kobheerian    freighter at Kora Two, where he's    worked as an instructor at a military    academy for the past five years.
Keep looking.
Don't worry, Major; I intend to.
I'll be with the prisoner if you    need me.
My compliments on your replicators,    Major; though this sem'hal stew could    use some yamok sauce.
I'm glad you're enjoying it.
Oh, I doubt that, Major; I doubt    that very much.
I hope it won't disturb your dinner    if I ask you a few questions.
And if I refuse?
I'll ask them anyway.
Yes, of course.
It is my job.
Persecuting Cardassians?  Oh, that    goes beyond your job, Major... That's    your passion.
You claim you weren't at Gallitep.
Yes, I missed that honor.
And that your illness is not Kalla-   Nohra.
Again, true.
Again false.  Our doctor verified    that you do have Kalla-Nohra, which    means you were at Gallitep.
If your lies are going to be that    transparent, this will be a short    interrogation.
In that case, I'll try to make my    lies more opaque.
What was your rank at Gallitep?     What were your duties?
You really don't want to know.
Just answer the question.
You're going to be very disappointed.
I'll risk it.
I had the distinction of serving in    the exalted position of...    (beat; leans forward     to confide)   ... Filing clerk.
Filing clerk?

You see?  I told you you'd be    disappointed.    (rises; conversational     pacing)   Actually, I would've been just as    happy to avoid military service    altogether.  Fortunately, I was lucky    enough to draw duty in the records    office at Gallitep.  As it turned    out, I proved an exemplary file clerk.     During my fourteen units of service,    not one report was lost or misfiled.     I was awarded numerous commendations.     Gul Darhe'el himself told me my    computer filing system was a    "masterpiece of meticulous    exactitude."       So now you know.  My secret is out;    my crime laid bare.       I await execution.
I hope we don't keep you waiting    long.       I've never heard of a filing clerk    becoming an instructor at a military    academy.
Until now.
And what did you teach?
Believe it or not...       Filing.
I can verify that.
Be my guest.
I still think you're a liar.
Ah.  So much for our search for the    truth.  Now we exchange insults.
You admit you worked under Gul    Darhe'el.
We all did.
I take it, then... you witnessed the    atrocities.
Atrocities?  What atrocities?
Oh, I do vaguely recall hearing a    scream now and then, but...       Atrocities?
Do you expect me to believe you knew    nothing about the murders... the    torture... You never saw the bodies?
Well of course I saw bodies.  People    died at Gallitep all the time.     Mining accidents; illnesses; feuds    among the workers...
You're saying Bajorans killed each    other?
At times.  Over food; a blanket; a    woman... Conditions were harsh, after    all.  It was a labor camp, Major.
I helped liberate that camp.  I saw    those bodies.  I saw how they died.

You saw what we wanted you to see.     Do you know who started the rumors    about brutality at Gallitep?  Gul    Darhe'el himself.  Now there was a    leader.  A brilliant, extraordinary    man.  He knew that to rule by fear    was to rule completely.       Why bother with actual mass murder,    when the mere reports of such    incidents achieved the same effect.
Which was?
Major, you know that as well as I    do.  To keep you Bajorans thinking    of yourselves as victims.  To keep    you scared... and helpless.
It turned out we weren't so helpless.     We did get rid of you.
Leaving was a political decision.       Now I've enjoyed reminiscing with    you, Major; but I really do think    it's time you let me out of here.
I can't do that.
No, of course not.  You see, Major,    you're the one who's lying now, not    me.  You're not interested in truth.     All you want is vengeance.
Commander, I was led to believe that    the Federation guaranteed safe and    unrestricted passage to all travelers    visiting your station.
That's correct.
Then how do you explain your detention    of a Cardassian citizen?

Marritza came here seeking medical    attention.  Right now, he's under    our doctor's care.  All we're trying    to do is verify his identity.  A    simple matter, if you'll give us    some assistance.

I assure you, Commander, you don't    require our assistance.  If your    patient says his name is Marritza,    then that's who he is.  I hope you're    not suggesting you don't trust him    simply because he's Cardassian.
I don't trust him because he's already    lied to us about his being at    Gallitep.
Is that what you're charging him    with, Commander?  Lying?
So far, we haven't charged him with    anything.
Then let him go.
I'd like nothing better.  But first    I need to know who it is I'm letting    go.
I appreciate the awkwardness of your    position, Commander.  This Bajoran    obsession with alleged Cardassian    improprieties during the occupation,    is really quite distasteful.
I suppose if you're a Bajoran, so    was the occupation.
I remind you that neither one of us    is Bajoran.  I'd hate their bitterness    to cause conflict between Cardassia    and the Federation.
I hope to avoid that, too... with    your help.
Commander, you don't need my help to    safeguard one Cardassian on your own    station.  If those Bajoran hate-   mongers get their hands on him, I'm    holding you responsible.
What're you looking for?
Answers.
Found any yet?
Marritza says I don't care about the    truth.  That all I want is vengeance.
Are you worried he might be right... ?
All I want is to see him punished.
Even if he is just a file clerk?
That's just it... I don't want him    to be a file clerk.  I want him to    be... I don't know... worse than    that...
You want him to be guilty.
As far as I'm concerned, if he was    at Gallitep, he is guilty.  They    were all guilty.  Don't you see, his    punishment will make all of Bajor    feel... some...       ...satisfaction.

It sounds like you're trying too    hard to believe what you're saying.     You already know if you punish him    without reason, it won't mean    anything.  And you already know    vengeance isn't enough.
Re-route the signal enhancement module    to the main sensor array.
Aye, Sir.
How's it look?
Give me a second; I'll run a    diagnostic.       It's ready.

I've checked with the Bajoran    Archives, and they do have a Marritza    on record as being a file clerk at    Gallitep.  I also checked with the    military academy on Kora Two.     Marritza has been teaching filing    there just as he claims.
All set, Commander.
Major?       How many images were sent from the    Bajoran archives?
Only one.       It's the only picture they could    find of Gallitep that had Marritza    in it.  The Cardassians destroyed    almost all records of the occupation.
The image enhancement and    transformation functions are patched    directly into your console.
Major, what if this image confirms    that Marritza was a file clerk?     What do you expect us to do, then?
I suppose you'll let him go.
I'm glad we understand each other.
I've got it.
On screen.
Which one is Marritza?
Let's see... According to the caption,    he's the one in the background; on    the far right.
Isolate and magnify.
We're going to have to do better    than that.
Give me a minute; I'm running an    image enhancement sequence.
It's not him.
Are you sure we're looking at the    right man?
(double-checking     console)   Background... far right... Aamin    Marritza.
It can't be.
If that's Marritza, then who are we    holding?
Lieutenant... Isolate the Cardassians    in the foreground.
The one in profile on the left...    What can you give us, Dax?
That's him... That's Marritza.
Not according to the caption.
What d'you mean?
According to this... It's Gul    Darhe'el.
Ah.  Let me guess.  You've come back    to learn the secret of my filing    system.
I know all your secrets now.
Is that so.
What did you do?  Kill the real    Marritza, so you could take his place?     Well, you'll pay for that death; and    all the others you're responsible    for.
I'm afraid I couldn't possibly pay    for all of them, Major.  After all,    there were so many... and you can    only execute me once.
That's my only regret.  But I'll    settle for knowing that Bajor will    finally have the satisfaction of    punishing "The Butcher of Gallitep."
Tell me, Major; did you figure it    all out by yourself, or did you need    help from your Federation masters?
I'll let you wonder about that.     It'll keep you occupied while we're    waiting for the provisional government    to prepare your war crimes tribunal.

War crimes?  How could there be war    crimes, when there wasn't any war?       Of course, I can understand how you    might wish there had been a war...    Your need to indulge some pathetic    fantasy of brave Bajoran soldiers    marching to an honorable defeat.     But in fact, Major, you and I both    know there was no war; no glory;    Bajor didn't resist.  It just    surrendered.
The Bajorans were a peaceful people    before you came.  We were no threat    to you.  We could never understand    why you had to be so brutal.
Well we can't have that.  You see,    Major, I don't want there to be any    more secrets between us.  So whatever    you don't understand, I'll explain.
Thank you, but I think I've heard    enough of your lies.

What lies?  You mean my failure to    divulge my true identity?  Believe    me, I yearned to tell you.  But I    knew how much more satisfying it    would be for you to find out for    yourself.  And believe me, Major;    that was my only deception.  Marritza?     He was a magnificent file clerk.     And I, Gul Darhe'el?  I hope you    won't think it immodest of me when I    say that I was a magnificent leader.     You never saw Gallitep at its    height.  As a labor camp, it was the    very model of order and efficiency.     And why?  For that, you must look to    the top.  To me!
My word, my merest glance, was law.     And my verdict was always the same:    Guilty.
You're insane.
No, no, no, Major... I'm sorry, but    you can't dismiss me that easily.  I    did what needed to be done.

My men understood that... which is    why they loved me.  I'd order them    to go out and murder Bajoran scum,    and they would do it... They'd come    back covered in blood... and still    feel clean.  Yes, Major... clean.     And why did they feel that way?...    Because they were clean!
So then you admit your atrocities.

I admit everything.  Why not?  I was    the best at what I did.  My    accomplishments speak for themselves.     Can you say the same?       You and that little Shakaar resistance    cell you belonged to.  You did nothing    but annoy Cardassians, while I was    busy exterminating Bajorans.
Make sure you tell that to the    tribunal.
Oh, I will.
And they'll sentence you to death.

Let them.  Don't you see; it'll change    nothing!  Kill me.  Torture me... it    doesn't matter.  You've already lost,    Major.  You can never undo what I've    accomplished.  The dead will still    be dead!
(laughs; calls after     her)   What're you going to do now, Major?     Withhold my medicine?
What is it?
Maraltian Seev-ale; from Quark's    private stock.
Better?
You know, Odo... I wonder how many    others like Darhe'el are still out    there... Still free... unpunished...
Quite a few, no doubt.  But thanks    to you, there's one less out there    now.
You should've heard him... He bragged    about what happened at Gallitep.     The torture... the rape... the    humiliation.  He's proud of what he    did to us.
Why don't you go to your quarters,    and lie down for a while.  We'll    leave him alone with his Cardassian    pride.
I don't want to lie down.  That's    what he'd like.  Another Bajoran    hiding in a corner.  He's probably    in there laughing at me now.
He won't be laughing very long.

I hate him, Odo.  I hate that    smirking, superior Cardassian face.     When I was fighting with the    resistance, we used to lie awake at    night plotting the assassination of    men like him.  And now I have to    stand there and listen to him belittle    the Shakaar and everything it stood    for.
Perhaps you should avoid discussing    your personal history with a creature    like that.
I didn't.
Then how did he know you were with    the Shakaar?
I don't know... He was an important    military leader...

That doesn't explain it.  If he'd    been in charge of quelling Bajoran    resistance, then he might've had    your name on file.  But he commanded    a forced labor camp.       Something's not right here.
Where are you going?
To have another little chat with Gul    Darhe'el.
Computer... Review all off-station    requests for information regarding    Major Kira Nerys within the last    eight months.
...Working...
Back again to see "the butcher"...    Am I really that fascinating?
How did you know I was with the    Shakaar?
That provisional government of yours    certainly moves slowly.  They    should've dragged me away in chains    by now.
Answer the question.

My, my, you are a strutting little    egotist.  You forget the brilliance    of Marritza's filing system.  He saw    to it that I was provided with    information on all your little    terrorist bands.  I especially enjoyed    the termination reports.  You see,    life at a forced labor camp can be    so isolating.  At times I felt that    only I bore the burden of cleansing    Bajor of its rabble.  Those reports    reassured me that I was not alone.
And I'm supposed to believe that you    remember my name from some report    you read years ago?
At the risk of bruising your vanity    even further, Major... I didn't    remember your name at all until I    heard it here.       I can see that disturbs you.
Hardly.
You know, Major, they will be coming    for me soon, so... Before we say    goodbye, there are a few little    questions I'd like to ask you.
Your questions don't interest me.
What makes you so sure?       Or are you just afraid to hear them?
Who're they?
Survivors of Gallitep.  They arrived    early this morning.  I suppose they're    waiting for justice.
Gallitep.  Imagine living through    that hellhole.  The pain... the    sorrow...       D'you think they like to gamble?
Doctor, I need your help.
Of course.
Three months ago, a request came    from Kora Two for information    concerning Kira Nerys.
To what purpose?
I'm not sure.  But the name on the    request was Aamin Marritza.       I've established a subspace link    with Kora Two.  I'd like you to access    his medical history there.
Dax to Odo... Gul Dukat is responding    to your subspace transmission.
Could you route it to my office.
I've missed working with you, Odo.     I've missed our games of kalevian    montar.
As I recall, Gul Dukat, we played    one game, and you cheated.

Same old Odo; like a blunt instrument.     Now; to answer your question... I    regret that I cannot give you access    to any files on Gul Darhe'el.     However, I assure you that the files    would only tell you what I'm telling    you... Gul Darhe'el is dead.
That's impossible.
I attended the funeral myself.  As a    matter of fact, he's buried under    one of the largest military monuments    on Cardassia.
Then who are we holding here?
An innocent Cardassian citizen, just    as I explained to your Commander    Sisko.  And we want him released.
That innocent citizen has admitted    he is Gul Darhe'el.
What?  What are you talking about!
He says his name is Gul Darhe'el.
Then he's lying!
If he is, it's the most foolish lie    he could've invented.  It's likely    to get him executed.  Why would anyone    do such a thing?
I don't know.  But I tell you I was    at Darhe'el's funeral.
You're sure the man you saw buried    was Gul Darhe'el?
Half of Cardassia viewed his body!
I saw a photograph of Darhe'el taken    at the Gallitep labor camp.  It    certainly appears to be the man we're    holding.
You are mistaken!  This is obviously    a plot to embarrass the Cardassian    Empire.
It's possible.  Give me access to    your files and perhaps I can find    some proof to support your claim    that Gul Darhe'el is dead.
I suppose I could grant you limited    access to the files...
I think that's wise.
... I was twelve when I started    fighting... but I know of some who    started even younger than that.
Yes, yes, but let's get to the real    issue... How many Cardassians did    you kill?  I mean personally.
Oh, I think you did.  And I'm sure    your total wasn't limited to military    personnel.  After all, one of the    most effective terrorist weapons was    random violence.
Don't leave now, Major... Not when    it's finally getting good.  How many    Cardassian civilians did you kill?
Look... I regret a lot of what I had    to do.
How convenient of you.
We had no choice!  We were fighting    for survival!

So were we!  We had an empire to    protect.  We needed your resources!       Everything I did was for the greater    glory of Cardassia!  And if you    spineless scum had to be ground under,    so much the better!  All that mattered    was Cardassia!  I loved my homeland!     That's what justified my actions;    that's what gave me my strength.
Nothing justifies genocide.
What you call genocide... I called a    day's work!
Major?  May we talk outside, please?
Doctor Bashir and I have done some    checking.  I don't know why yet...    but the man in that cell... wanted    to be caught.
This certificate of death was in the    file sent to me by Gul Dukat.
According to this, Gul Darhe'el died    in his sleep six years ago.       "Cause of death:  Massive Coleibric    hemorrhage."
Commander, I guarantee you that's a    forged document.  I think it's pretty    clear what's going on here.  The    Cardassians want to trick us into    letting him go.
I wouldn't put it past our friend    Gul Dukat.
Nor would I.  However...
The man in there confessed that he's    Gul Darhe'el.
Major, the man in there has Kalla-   Nohra Syndrome.
Of course he does.
According to the evidence I've been    sent, Gul Darhe'el never contracted    that condition.
More evidence from the trustworthy    Gul Dukat.
What've you got, Constable?
Darhe'el's progress reports from    Gallitep show that, when the mining    accident occurred, he was back on    Cardassia being awarded the Proficient    Service Medallion.
If he wasn't at Gallitep on the day    of the accident, he couldn't have    contracted Kalla-Nohra.
Correct.  But the man we're holding    does have it.
I don't believe I'm listening to    this.

I'm afraid there's more, Major.  I    inquired about his last two weeks on    Kora Two.  He resigned his position    at the military academy; put all his    affairs in order... even provided    handsomely for his housekeeper, I    understand...
All right; so like most criminals,    he wanted to move on before somebody    traced his whereabouts.
He specifically requested passage on    a vessel scheduled to stop here...    at a Bajoran station.  A rather    unusual request for a Cardassian war    criminal...
Unless he wanted to be captured.

Wait a minute.  Let's be clear about    one thing:  This "evidence" may raise    some interesting questions.     Nevertheless, Darhe'el is going to    be sent to Bajor to stand trial for    the atrocities he committed.
Major, that's still to be decided.
Then go talk to him!  If you still    have any doubts, just listen to what    he has to say... He was there; he    did it; he'll tell you about it!
Constable, I've checked Marritza's    medical records.
What've we got?
He's been under treatment for Kalla-   Nohra Syndrome, of course... and a    few other minor ailments, most    relating to his age... It's all fairly    standard, actually... Except for one    thing.
Which is?
Five years ago, when he arrived on    Kora Two, he was taking massive doses    of a dermatiraelian plastiscine.
It's a dermal regenerative agent.     It maintains skin resilience following    cosmetic alteration.
(beaten; not even a     question now)   You're saying he's had his face    changed to look like Gul Darhe'el.
It certainly appears that way.
How're you feeling?

I was starting to get bored, but    seeing you again brightens my day.     Or is it night?  It doesn't matter.     What's important is that it's time    for another one of our chats.  What    shall it be this time?  Why don't I    lecture you on various Cardassian    torture techniques.
I was referring to your Kalla-Nohra    Syndrome.  Do you want to see Doctor    Bashir?

Ah, so that's it.  You were hoping    to see me writhe around on the floor    in pain.  Do you really think a    Cardassian would put on such a    deplorable display in front of a    Bajoran?  You don't understand us at    all, do you?
I'm beginning to understand a great    deal about you.  But one thing does    puzzle me.
And what would that be?
How you contracted Kalla-Nohra    syndrome.
Did you think that mining accident    only affected the Bajoran laborers,    and not their Cardassian masters?     That would've been very nice.
So you're saying you were at Gallitep    when that mining accident occurred?
Of course.  Why are we going over    this again?
Because your own progress reports    show that you were back on Cardassia    at the time of the accident...
Ridiculous!
... Receiving your Proficient Service    Medallion.
Then the reports are wrong.
I can show them to you.
That won't be necessary; I know where    I was.
Why were you taking a dermal    regenerative?
I don't know what you're talking    about.
Then let me help you.  Five years    ago... when you first got to Kora    Two...
That's enough; your presence no longer    amuses me... Get out.
Why did you have your face altered?
Security guard!  Security!  I want    this woman out of here!  Security!
Why are you pretending to be Gul    Darhe'el?

Why don't you ask me something    intelligent, such as how I felt when    I heard we were withdrawing from    Bajor?  My answer is, I was furious!     The thought of leaving behind any    survivors was repulsive to me.
So while the useless office clerks    were busy packing their precious    files, I ordered my overseers to    begin slaughtering the laborers.
If you felt that way about your office    clerks, why did you take Marritza's    name?
My plan was to do nothing less than    kill every Bajoran in the camp!  To    this day, I regret that we were unable    to achieve that honorable goal.
You're Marritza, aren't you?
You mistake me for that bug?  That    wimpering nothing?  You stupid Bajoran    girl, don't you know who I am?  I am    your nemesis; I am you're nightmare;    I am the "Butcher of Gallitep!"
"The Butcher of Gallitep" died six    years ago.  You're Aamin Marritza,    his file clerk.
That's not true!  I'm alive!  I'll    always be alive!  It's Marritza who's    dead!  Marritza; who was only good    for cowering under his bunk and    weeping like a woman.

Every night, covering his ears so he    wouldn't have to hear the Bajorans    screaming for mercy while we killed    them... covering my ears... so I    wouldn't have to hear those terrible    screams!  You don't know what it's    like to be a coward.  To stand by    and let such horrors take place, and    do nothing.  No; Marritza's dead.     He deserves to be dead.
What are you doing!
I'm letting you go.
Security!  Security guard!  Get in    here!  Help me!  Security!
You didn't commit those crimes; and    you couldn't stop them.  You were    only one man.

No; don't you see?  I have to be    punished.  We all have to be punished.       Major, you have to go out there and    tell them; tell them I'm Gul Darhe'el.     It's the only way; don't you see    that?
Why are you doing this?

For Cardassia.  Cardassia will never    survive unless it stands in front of    Bajor and admits the truth.  My trial    will force Cardassia to acknowledge    its guilt.  And we are guilty... all    of us.  Don't you see, my death is    necessary.
What you're asking for is another    murder.  Enough good people have    already died.  I won't help kill    another.
You should be back on Kora Two in    three days.
There's nothing for me to go back    to.
We've contacted officials there;    they'll be waiting to help you.
If they had believed I was Gul    Darhe'el, my trial might have helped    bring about a new Cardassia.       But, now you've told them I was only    a file clerk...
What you tried to do was very    honorable.  Maybe, one day other    Cardassians will acknowledge the    truth of what they did to Bajor.
Why!  He wasn't Darhe'el!  Why!
He's a Cardassian.  That's reason    enough.
No...       ... It's not.
